course.subject: SCIE
course.name: Chemistry and Life
course.description: This course is intended for students with no science background. It helps students learn about life from chemical aspects and develop a sense of enquiry thinking in science. The course will lay the knowledge foundation by a brief introduction of chemistry of life from molecular level to human body and then ecological level, followed by selected topics on the subject with scientific focus, such as tests with DNA, cell signaling and metabolism; with health focus, such as nutrition, genetic engineering and diseases; and finally with the ecological focus such as the pollution and clean energy.
course.exclusions: Any 2000-level or above courses in CHEM, LIFS, CENG, BIEN

reviews.author: RZ
reviews.title: Good course with good & transparent grade
reviews.comment_content:
Good course with good content, 30% A range with 178 participants (Spring, 2020), almost 60 students got A range.
A and B accounted for 75% in total.

My friend from mainland said it's easy for him, but I did well and got an A too. And I think he was just bragging.

Content:
Chemistry in water
The chemistry of sugars and other carbohydrates
Cell membranes system
Life molecules
Food & Health

Amino acids and peptides
Nucleic acids and DNA
Protein
Enzymes
Lipids
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. NAGL:
He picks comprehensive contents
Mainly focus on Chemistry, especially basic organic chemistry

Prof. WONG:
He picks interesting topics e.g. foods and nutritions
Mainly focus on Life Science

Prof. ZHU:
He picks amazing and technical topics e.g. Genes and Heredity
Mainly focus on Life Science
reviews.comment_grading:
30% A range, large class size.
50% on Midterm (50 MC questions)
50% on the Final (50 MC questions)

Letter grade in Spring 2020:
A: 58/178 students (32%)
B: 77/178 students (43%)
C: 33/178 students (20%)
D: 2/178 students (1%)
F: 8/178 students (4%)

Midterm
Mean (Total): 37.7/50, SD: 6.0
Mean (SSCI): 38.4/50, SD: 5.8
Mean (SBM): 37.2/50, SD: 5.2
Mean (SENG): 36.0/50, SD: 7.2

Though it's a science course, many SBM students can do it very well too, according to the data published. If you are SSCI or SENG students, then it's not hard for you to get a good grade.

Final (Open-book because of COVID-19)
Mean: 44.5/50
SD: TBA

For more details on grades distribution, please kindly see the file attached↓
reviews.comment_workload:
No quiz/assignment
No presentation/project
No essay/report to write
No attendance
Only 1 midterm and 1 final, and all MC

The workload is fair this semester, maybe because of the covid-19 outbreak and all exams are open-book. Just follow the steps of professors and you can handle it very well.

reviews.author: cylam
reviews.title: LIFS students have absolute advantage, especially the senior ones
reviews.comment_content: find it in the attachment or scroll down for other comments
reviews.comment_teaching:
Herrup:
very funny prof. but he retired after this semester so I don't know how the syllabus would change next year.
Some of the ppt are exactly the same from LIFS1902 last semester but he would teach it more simply than 1902.

Nagl:
A good guy who would give us candy in mt :)
He got an accent and speaks quite fast so it is difficult to catch what he said, but don't worry, ALL of the points can be found in the ppt. (and not all of them will be included in the mt, he would tell u in lesson)
The exercise he gave us is important (especially the test exam, the format is VERY similar to that of real midterm, he doesn't want to make it to difficult for non-science school student although it is undeniable that LIFS students will have absolute advantages than student from other major)

Wong:
Nice guy but his lessons may be a bit boring for some students(not me although I got friends who can't take it)
The content is quite easy. Mostly about nutrients we take. He take care of the fill-in-the-blank in final which is a bit challenging. but u will be fine if u studied hard.
reviews.comment_grading:
I am a year 1 student who take LIFS1902 (grade: A-) in fall semester. I did study hard but the grade is not as good as i expected.
Maybe i will score better if i take it later in year 3 or 4.

MT: above ~0.5-1 s.d. (position: 3x/135 with 1 no-show)
final: no idea but should be fine, at least Im confident (full-mark: 50+5 bonus, max only 50 marks count towards the final grade)

grade: B+

Details of mt can be found in the attachment.
reviews.comment_workload:
very light workload, just mt and final although non-science student may find it quite challenging to memorize all the stuff needed.

mt(Nagl)(exam-time: 90 min):
the time is stressed to take care all those structures and names of amino acids. (don't worry, u can dump almost all those knowledge after mt).
the format is similar to the test exam so u should be find if u study hard.

final(Herrup and Wong)(exam-time: 3 hours):
straight forward and simple, AT LEAST half of the students left the room after 1 hour of the exam. but the result did't come out so i don't really know my performance.

reviews.author: ym7135
reviews.title: Don't take this course unless you have some biochemistry knowledge
reviews.comment_content:
This course comprises of 3 main sections taught by 3 professors. As a early third year BCB student, I can say this course is pretty much a summary of many LIFS courses, sometimes even reaching their level of complexity, I personally had to study for it too (I thought it would be an easy A without studying), I have no idea how business, engineering or math students could handle it.

Summary of the chapters:

Professor Nagl - Biochemistry (directly the same content as LIFS2210 - Biochemistry I, with some more extra physics)
- Microscopy  
- Chemistry of water
- Carbohydrates
- DNA
- Proteins
- Molecular proteins and muscle contraction (this reached LIFS3040 knowledge)
- Enzyme
- Lipids
- Analytical systems (even going to CHEM2311 content ...)

Professor Raymond Wong - Origin of life and metabolism (This was a throwback to LIFS2220, especially the part on lipids)
- Membrane systems
- Food and health
- Consuming sugars
- Ketogenic diet
- Sugar and intelligence

Professor Karl Herrup - Biological systems (his part was a throwback to LIFS1902 and a bit about respiration from LIFS2220):
- Evolution
- Mitochondria (TCA and ETC pathways)
- Nervous System
- Development
- Aging

As you can see, they took bits of 3-4 LIFS courses packed into one. LIFS students - particularly BCB has a huge advantage over everyone else because everything in this course has been taught prior.

Mid term was basically only Nagl's part (his entire part is exactly the entire course of LIFS2210, he squeezed a whole course into about 11-12 lectures).

While the finals were non-cumulative and is Herrup and Wong's part (they alternated randomly when lecturing their chapters)

Overall this course would be very overwhelming to non-LIFS students.
reviews.comment_teaching:
My rating and comment for each professor:

Stefan Nagl (C)
- His teaching was okay, but the biggest issue was that he over-estimates how much the students know - he goes straight to LIFS2210 parts assuming all students have prior knowledge already. The pacing was okay for me cuz I already took LIFS2210, but even year 1 LIFS students were struggling, yet alone those form other majors.
- He also goes through the material very quickly (legit crammed all of LIFS2210, not even kidding).
- Do expect very high level of memorization for his part, as you would need to directly recite them for his essay questions.

Raymond Wong (B):
- His teaching mainly revolved around diet, fats, sugar and health.
- His explanations are good, like he explains a lot of the links between foods, diseases, health threats ...
- However he may tend to over-explain and give a lot of details (not all are needed, they can be pretty interesting), some of his slides too list a huge no. of diseases (e.g. consequences of hyperglycaemia). A majority of his extra details or lists are not even examined.

Karl Herrup (A+)
- Easily the best professor in LIFS (he is at the top position too).
- His parts were from his 1902 classes, but he made is much easier and accessible to all students.
- Can easily follow through his content, he designed it so its easy to understand.

Overall teaching for this course: B, could have been better by focusing on main ideas and concepts of Chemistry and Life rather than huge details.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% Mid term (mean was barely a 70%, s.d. was about 10%, the exam was out of 111%, 11% was from bonus)
50% Finals (unknown mean or s.d., the exam itself was out of 55, 5% was bonus)

Mid-terms exams was fully short questions and essays, he had like 25-26 questions, and this also involved drawing specific amino acids, glucose, protein tertiary structures, DNA nucleotides, enzyme kinetics .... it was intense even for me!

Finals was much easier than mid-terms - Wong's part had 12MCQ and 13 Fill in the blanks, Herrup's part was 28 MCQ and 2 FIll in the blanks.

What was good is that in both mid-term and finals was that a certain% of it were bonus marks, so some wrong answers previously can be subsided.

I put the grading as A because I am a BCB student, as it was the perfect opportunity to leech off the bad grades from students of other majors to get a good grade (I am so sorry...)
reviews.comment_workload:
High workload to cram for mid-term content.
The workload is much less after mid-terms.

Also depends on what your major is, LIFS students have it much easier because they most likely learnt this before, while I have seen some business and math students really struggle and some eventually gave up.

reviews.author: fmlust
reviews.comment_content: Chemistry part is similar to what I have learnt in DSE chemistry. May cover some extra topics. Life science part is about DNA and related areas so could be hard for people who doesn't have any prior knowledge in chemistry and biology.
reviews.comment_teaching:
chemistry part: stefan nagl
life science part: zhu guang
Lectures are a bit boring so I just read powerpoints before the exams.
reviews.comment_grading: Good grading. Even if you put in a little effor you can get a B range if you have some basic knowledge on chemistry and life science.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. Only one midterm for chemistry part, and one term paper and one final exam for life science part.

reviews.author: Angelhui
reviews.title: 幾好grade s&t ssc
reviews.comment_content:
mt 前chem part mt 後bio part, 最好有讀dse 同chem 先入黎讀
chem:
chemistry in water
sugar
carbohydrates
nucleic acids
DNA
AA proteins
enzymes
lipids
bio part:
Nucleic acids
DNA double helix
DNA: molecule of heredity
DNA replication and repair
Protein biosynthesis
Cell metabolism
Diseases caused by genetic disorder
Introduction to Biotechnology
bio is a bit difficult for me
reviews.comment_teaching:
chem: stefan nagl
bio: zhu guang
兩個我都覺得悶，照讀ppt, 所以冇乜上堂
stefan 會比份test exam, 話係比你practice the style of midterm exam 但會出返有d題目, 其他題目都幾直接,就係出分出得太慢, 3月midterm 6 月考完final 先出分
zhu guang 一份都冇比，所以final 淨係溫ppt 就得，出得幾straightforward
reviews.comment_grading:
幾好grade
20幾% A range
50幾% B range
剩低C range and D
midterm 冇出overall mean, me 26/32
final mean 37/45 ,highest 44/45, me below mean 2 分
term paper mean 78.21/100, highest 95/100, me 95/100
at last overall around 85%A-
reviews.comment_workload:
50% midterm
30% final
20% term paper(5 pages essay)
no hw

reviews.author: jhaj
reviews.title: Easy but annoying
reviews.comment_content:
Content basically comprises of all the stuff taught in other general science courses like LIFS1902, CHEM1030, LIFS2040 but only surface level. It's really quite easy, especially if you already have some background in biology and chemistry. Even if you only took biology/chemistry in high school you will probably be able to do okay in this course if they work hard enough.

In my semester:
Midterm
1. Chemistry in water
2. Chemistry in sugars
3. Sugar chains make carbohydrates
4. Amino acids and peptides
5. 3D proteins
6. Membrane system

Finals
7. Nucleic acids
8. DNA double helix
9. DNA: molecule of heredity
10: DNA replication and repair
11. Protein biosynthesis
12. DNA / enzyme catalysis
13. Lipids
*******ps. I think there were more but I forgot. Just refer to this as a general image of what this course is like
reviews.comment_teaching:
prof Nagl:
Honestly isn't the most entertaining, sounds as if he is just reading off a script. His Accent could be a little confusing but if you focus just a little bit its fine. The ppts are decent but sometimes there are just paragraphs of explanations rather than bullet points. But since I often skipped the actual lecture- it was online anyways lol- and watched the recorded videos or just read the ppt, I found that the info on the ppts is actually sufficient and I didn't necessarily have to watch the whole lecture video. Helpful if you always cram like I do!

Prof Wong:
Teaching wise he's mediocre, accent sometimes disturbing but manageable. HOWEVER my biggest problem with him was when he graded our midterm exam. After grades came out I checked which questions I got wrong and why and found that he marked 3 questions that I clearly thought was right to be wrong. I double checked this too before I emailed him. 1 question he admitted to right away but the other 2 questions he just WOULDNT accept that these are the right answers. And these answers were literally on HIS OWN ppt. I screenshotted each ppt slide and showed it to him and all he replied was some bullshit explanation. It wasn't even just me, it was many other students as well. After sending over 5 emails he finally admitted to the second question, but in the end he didn't budge with the third question when so many students were sending him emails about this. Honestly so annoying, guys make sure to always check how you got questions wrong and double check it - and get evidence and tell the professor, even if sometimes your professor may be prof. Wong.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got midterm 44/50 and final 48/50
overall: A

Kinda still pissed because I was 1 point away from an A+ and maybe if I got that 1 extra point back from the midterm I might have gotten an A+. Or I don't know maybe it wouldn't have made a difference since everyone else's points would also go up.

Finals were honestly very unfair because
1. Content was VERY EASY (answer choices were copied exactly off from the ppt and such
2. Open book + ALLOW GOOGLE SEARCH
So like it would actually be dumb NOT to get a good grade on the final. I studied for this course aiming for an A+ and because of this, I felt that students who didn't actually study were all able to do well on the final, so the mean for the final was hella high - I think it was 44/50 ish.
I'm happy with my grade but still think that final was basically a legal cheatshow where everyone who didn't study were also able to do well on the exam. I guess once ftf classes resume--which I have no idea when--this won't be a problem.
reviews.comment_workload: No assignments, doesn't really check attendance, just midterm and final. Just content wise as well, not much work required. I skipped like 90% of live lectures and studied only 4 days for midterm and 6 days for final, mostly reviewing ppts. This was only possible because I already have a strong background in both biology and chemistry, and because I'm very adapted to pulling late night studies and overnighters hahah I don't recommend it though don't be like me :/

reviews.author: JOSIEwang
reviews.title: Best Graded CCC
reviews.comment_content: the best grading CCC I have found in UST. All those three professors took turns to deliver the lecture. And the German Professor Stefan is responsible for answering grading questions and other non-academic inquiry. He is quite nice.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Stefan NAGL is from CHEM and he taught the chemical characteristics of organic compounds like protein, DNA, carbon-hydrogen.

Prof WONG  is from LIFS and he just has 3 lectures, talking about different utility of those organic compounds and chemical reactions happening in the human body. like physiology.

Prof ZHU also from BIO and he specified on DNA replication, transcription,translation
reviews.comment_grading: 40% B range
reviews.comment_workload: 0 workload, 50% final 50% midterm

reviews.author: GGEZzzzz
reviews.title: Good Grade, Acceptable Workload
reviews.comment_content:
If you have zero prior knowledge of chemistry and biology and looking for a beginning science course, this course is not recommended.
Even with DSE biology knowledge, the LIFS part is not easy to catch up with as it contains lots of content about DNA replication, transcription, transportation etc.
The Chemistry part doesn't require examination for this semester so you can just google everything for the term paper and I believe most of us are pretty good at amateur sleuthing.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Chemistry Section (NAGL,Stefan):
Not an entertaining professor. Deep and boring voice with script-reading type of teaching method.

Lifs Science Section (ZHU, Guang):
Also not the most exciting lecturer, with a strong mainland accent.

Since participation is not required in this course, I suggest you just read the slides on your own and ask your science friends for clarification. The slides are pretty detailed(contain way more information then you would need for the exam).
reviews.comment_grading:
Final Grade: A+
Essay Score:
Chemistry Term Paper (50%) : 93/100 (highest)
Life Science Term Paper (30%): 42/50.
Final Quiz (20%) : 40/44.
I wouldn't say getting an A+ is easy, but B range is pretty attenable even if you don't put in much effort.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite heavy workload.
No participation requirement. No in-class quizzes. Two essay (one for chemistry and one for life science). The essay length is about 3000 words (if you want good grades) and frankly speaking it takes quite a lot of time to do research. There is one final quiz for life science part (to quiz or not to quiz is subjected to the professor) which is just straight based on the material given in the lecture and it is pretty straight forward.

reviews.author: Karen2018
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm (taught by Prof Ngal and Prof Wong)
- Chemistry in water
- The chemistry of sugars
- Sugar chains make carbohydrates
- Carbohydrates
- Evolution of membranes / systems I  
- Evolution of membranes / systems II
- Life molecules for health / diseases (Food & health through metabolism I)    
- Food & health through metabolism II  
- Human Intelligence
- The chemistry of amino acids and peptides
- How to build a three-dimensional protein

Final (taught by Prof Ngal and Prof Zhu)
- The chemistry of nucleic acids
- DNA: The double helix and beyond
- The blueprint of life: Nucleic acids and genes
- DNA: the molecule of heredity
- DNA replication and cell division
- Protein biosynthesis
- Diseases caused by genetic disorder
- Introduction to Biotechnology
- Enzymatic catalysis
- The chemistry of lipids

Planned but didn't have time to teach
- Microscopy – The art of seeing the small
- Analytical systems: Monitoring of health and disease
reviews.comment_teaching:
My background: SBM student who studied DSE Chem but not Bio

Prof Ngal
- Quite good becoz he spent time on reviewing previous lecture or related content which may help us build a better understanding
- But he rushed on the last lecture and spent only 30 mins to finish the lipids part as he would like to include this part in final

Prof Wong
- The content was easy to understand but he prepared quite challenging questions in the midterm

Prof Zhu
- He taught DNA and I think it is the most difficult part in this course
- But the questions were so easy that you can find all the answers in ppt
reviews.comment_grading:
Better than expectation coz I didn't score high marks in the midterm

Midterm: 39/50 (Mean:38, High:47)
Final: 49/50 (Mean:44.1, High:50)

Grade: B+
But I wish I can get 1 more mark and then I would have got A- ...QAQ
reviews.comment_workload:
1 Midterm and 1 Final
Just spend few days on studying ppt

Questions in the final were super easy and you got plenty of time to finish them

reviews.author: BOvyyy
reviews.title: Not recommended for non-science students
reviews.comment_content:
NEVER UNDERESTIMATE THIS COURSE
This course is said to target at students who did not have much science background. Although I am a business student in UST, I actually studied Bio and Chem for DSE. But I found the content to be too in-depth and a lot harder than the content needed for DSE. This course is also very cramped and the content is so overwhelming.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The teaching is basically useless. Because all
professors are quite boring and they just simply read the PowerPoint once. So actually you can skip all lessons and self-study. But to be fair, the professors are helpful and you can find them whenever you need.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% mid-term
50% final
I get bad grades but I still rank the grading B
because at least it is fair, all based on your effort. Just remember to put as much effort as you can.
reviews.comment_workload:
No assignments
But you definitely have to study very hard in order to get good grades in exam because the content is really too much.

reviews.author: Moo
reviews.title: Great course for Life Science students
reviews.comment_content:
Mid-term (only Prof. Nagl)

- Microscopy  
- Chemistry of water
- Carbohydrates
- DNA
- Proteins
- Molecular proteins and muscle contraction
- Enzyme
- Lipids
- Analytical systems

Final (Prof. Wong and Prof. Herrup)

- Membrane systems
- Food and health
- Consuming sugars
- Ketogenic diet
- Sugar and intelligence
- Evolution
- Mitochondria (TCA and ETC pathways)
- Nervous System
- Development
- Aging
reviews.comment_teaching: There are 3 sections taught by three different professors. It might be tough to get all the information from the lecture in 1.5 hours since Prof. Nagl, especially, finishes his 60 slides of ppt every lecture, but the lecture videos are provided so that you can catch up the parts that you missed in the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% Mid term (mean - 70%; s.d - 10%)
50% Finals (mean - unknown yet; s.d - unknown yet)
reviews.comment_workload: There are only one mid-term and one final for the course so you won't be stressed out due to any assignments. But since you need to study 12 ppts which are composed of nearly 60 slides only for the mid-term, it may be quite time-consuming. The workload is far less for the final so I guess it is fair enough.

reviews.author: Tornado
reviews.title: Meh
reviews.comment_content:
For biology students, these should be easy.

For non-biology students, these should be manageable.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Karl was boring, and we just could not really understand what he is talking about.

Professor Renneberg is much better, we could watch biology related MOVIES during class! And there are questions related to the movies in the exam. Therefore, technically it takes attendance.
reviews.comment_grading: No one knows how it grades, at least I got some good results in both mid term and final, and I got a C, which does not make sense anyway.
reviews.comment_workload:
One Mid term, one final

No homework

reviews.author: ycrlo
reviews.comment_content:
50% LIFS and 50% CHEM (or actually Biotech)

Prof. Wong gave lectures on the basics of Phy Chem and Bio. Content was alright to me since I have taken Physics and Chemistry in high school. Only four short ppts, and should be manageable for all students.
Prof. Herrup's part: DNA, the nervous system, the immune system and sth related to fertilisation. Only the lecture on DNA was less boring to me .. His ppts are all super long (at least 60 slides per lesson). He told us in the first lecture that he would be gentle to us since most of us aren't science students.. but honestly the content is still too much for non-science students. Indeed struggled quite hard before the midterm exam because of his parts.....
Prof Renneberg is from the Chemistry Dept. His topics included metabolism, proteins and enzymes, infections and high speed of science. Classes are quite interactive and lively.
All three professors' topics are not quite related, but luckily the final isn't cumulative, so you only have to revise Prof. Wong and Prof. Herrup's parts for the midterm (mainly LIFS), and focus on Prof. Renneberg's parts for the Final (CHEM).
Should be pretty easy for science students, but as a business student, the content is simply overloading, esp. for the first half..
reviews.comment_teaching:
I was enrolled into the course right before the end of the add-drop period, so I missed 80% of Prof. Wong's lectures. Not much special about this prof.
Prof. Herrup is the head of the LIFS Dept and is super demanding.
Both of them just read out the slides so not much to say about.
Prof. Rennengberg is my favourite among the three. Very funny prof and interesting classes. He prepared movies and other reading materials. He shared his own stories with us and focused on the applications of science, which are much more useful than other prof's lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
50% Midterm Exam
50% Final Exam
(Would be good if you don't want to take CCs with group projects.)

Midterm - MCQs (3-4 questions have multiple answers which made it rather confusing)
Final- MCs and one essay question

Grading was better than expected. Yet, I gave it a C because it's simply unfair not to exempt students who have taken related science courses like LIFS1902 and more advanced Bio/Chem/Biotech courses. Anyway, getting a B should not be a problem for most of the students if you got slightly above mean for the overall grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Not much workload since there are just two exams (1 midterm and 1 final). No assignments, no quizzes and no projects. 2-3 in-class exercises for bonus marks given by Prof. Renneberg. Need not attend lectures since lecture videos are uploaded after every class.

reviews.author: JE
reviews.title: Not bad
reviews.comment_content: It would be an advantage if you have taken the biology before. Since there are many terms and concepts related. For me I find it boring....
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Reinhard RENNEBERG is the most interesting lecturer among three. He prepares a movie and some short clips to demonstrate the content.
reviews.comment_grading: I found it difficult in both exams since honestly I did not work very hard on it. But outcome the grade was not bad. For two exams I almost below one SD, and finally I got a B-
reviews.comment_workload: No homework, just a midterm and exam.

reviews.author: darkflash
reviews.title: (Bio)chemistry and life
reviews.comment_content:
呢個course同chemistry course完全冇相似既地方，根本係第二個LIFS1902。

Prof. Zhu:
主要介紹DNA/RNA structure, DNA replication同埋translation+transcription。大部份content喺LIFS 1902講過，淨係讀過DSE Bio既話比較難catch up。

Prof. Renneberg:
教個course的一半，但成個sem得兩個powerpoint (加埋80頁)，其他時間就睇電影，播youtube片同做實驗。內容簡單，而且會講邊d唔考。

Prof. Herrup:
content量多，加加埋埋都200-300頁。佢教既topic係LIFS1902比較難既topic(nervous system同埋development)，完全同1902一樣。如果冇讀過，唔建議reg呢個course。
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Zhu:
講書都幾清晰，有少少口音。Notes幾詳盡，唔上堂都知佢做緊乜。

Prof. Renneberg:
上堂佢抄埋notes比你睇，講書清晰 (除左唔考嗰d content)。上堂會做好多搞笑野，好開心。但係final exam考少少離題野(例如睇電影既情節)，上堂最好100%專心。

Prof. Herrup:
講野超快，英文listening唔掂就完全聽唔明。Lecture note得圖冇字，完全唔知佢做緊乜。最好學Prof. Renneberg咁自己上youtube搵片睇。
reviews.comment_grading: 唔算fair，因為個course冇exclusion，major life science既同學都可以黎屈機。冇讀過LIFS 1902既話會好輸蝕。Course Grade都OK，overall above mean ~0.8個sd 有B+。
reviews.comment_workload:
得midterm+final，難度合理。

冇讀過LIFS1902就要付出3倍workload。

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.comment_content:
Topics include:
Cell as the fundamental building block
The molecules of Life
Nucleic acids and genes
DNA: The molecule of heredity
DNA replication and cell division
Protein biosynthesis
Proteins
Diseases caused by genetic disorder
Enzymes
Metabolism
Lipids and carbohydrates
Chemical signaling networks in cells
Tele-communications in the body
Viruses
Chemical interactions in morphogenesis
Our genome
Fighting infections
Fighting cancer
Chemistry and our Environment

The course title is 'Chemistry of Life' but in reality the course is a Biology / Biochemistry course. There is a lot of overlap with LIFS courses such as 1902 (General Biology II) and 2040 (Cell Biology).

The course content is not at all well structured. The 3 professors all teach different topics and they are not integrated, so it keeps switching from one topic to some completely different one.

The level of difficulty is too high for a 1000-level Common Core course meant for students with 'no scientific background'. Because it is mainly a Biology course there is a lot of memorization.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The system of 3 professors teaching different topics in the course doesn't work very well for this course because they all teach very different topics, sometimes not related to each other, and all teach in very different styles. Prof. Herrup and Zhu follow a very structured and organized teaching, with clear lecture notes for each of their topics and they usually just explain the slides during the lectures. They both explain the concepts quite clearly and are helpful with any questions.

Prof. Renneberg has a very different style of teaching which students either find very enjoyable or very frustrating. He does not follow any structure whatsoever. He almost never follows the given schedule and teaches any topic at any time. During each lecture also there is no structure as he discusses any topics, stories, jokes, facts, etc. No lecture notes are provided at any time and his content is not directly from any textbook so it's almost impossible to revise his content before the exams. Most of his lectures are spent watching him draw cartoons and watching random Hollywood movies (which are actually tested in the exams with 4 or 5 MCQ questions about the plot of the movies).
reviews.comment_grading:
Again the structure of this course makes the grading and exams very confusing.

Midterm and Final exams, weighting not revealed.

Midterm is only MCQs, but Prof. Renneberg's section is multiple-answer MCQs which makes the grading terrible as there is negative marking for missing a correct choice/choosing an incorrect choice.
Final has 2 papers, Prof. Herrup's part has mostly MCQs, Prof. Renneberg's part also has 2 long questions which involve drawing and designing some tests.
In both exams Prof. Renneberg's questions always include some MCQs about the plot and characters of the Hollywood movies shown in lectures (The Martian, Contagion, etc.) and some about random general knowledge trivia.

I got 0.5 SD above mean in midterm, >1 SD above mean in 1st final paper, slightly below mean in 2nd final paper, overall grade B.
reviews.comment_workload:
No workload at all. The exams require quite a lot of memorization of the lecture slides for Prof. Herrup and Zhu's parts, can't really prepare for Prof. Renneberg's part.

Prof. Renneberg has some optional HW I think which can give you 1 or 2% bonus points.

reviews.author: tklrs
reviews.comment_content:
This course is in general easy. Although it is titled as 'Chemistry and Life', most of the course's materials are biology related (eg. DNA, telecommunications in human bodies, viruses).

For biology part, basically it's about memorisation of different biological processes. Once you get yourself familiar with the details of each process, it should be easy to answer the questions in the exam.

For Chemistry part, you just need to review the concepts Professor Renneberg mentions in class, and his class notes already include everything you will need for the exam.

If you don't really like biology or have zero background about biology, this course is not recommended for you as it could be boring and a bit difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Renneberg usually interacts with students in class, like asking questions, sharing his interesting stories and playing course related videos. The other two professors just read out what they have on the powerpoint slides.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair in this course.
Both mid term and final exam consist of two parts, one for biology part and one for chemistry part.
Both MCQs and short questions appear on the biology part; while only short questions appear on the chemistry part.
If you can get 1 SD above in each exam, you should not be worried about getting a decent grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
No compulsory homework.

Only Professor Renneberg gives homework, however, you can just hand in if you want for extra points. He sometimes gives reading materials (based on videos he play in class or just some extra readings), which would also appear on the exam.

Some sample exam questions are also uploaded to the course site, which are quite useful to prepare for the exams.

reviews.author: makmakmakmak
reviews.title: If you haven't study Biology before, better not do it
reviews.comment_content:
Although it is called chem and life, but mostly it's about biochem, for example cell structure, DNA, virus, nervous system...
If you have studied Biology before, should be fairly easy for you. Also only enrol it if you have a great interest in the topics mentioned above, otherwise you would find it bored.

Mid-term: 2 papers, 50 marks each
Zhu - all Mc
Renneberg - 8 short questions

Exam: 2 papers, 50 marks each
Peng - MC + short questions
Renneberg - 8 questions including one long question that was about the film

This course is basically about memorising everything that you have learnt.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Renneberg's teaching was actually very good. It was fun and interesting. He likes to use movie to explain some science background, so most of his lecture time, we were watching different films. One thing is that, you must attend his lecture to copy down the notes. His ppt slides were basically pictures, so you would understand nothing simply by looking at them. Also, he would ask about the films that played in lecture in exam n mid-term. For the other profs, they usually just teach whats in the ppt.
reviews.comment_grading:
Even though it says this course is for students with no science background, anyone can take this course, so many biochem students would also reg this, therefore they will pull up the grades boundaries. Most of these students got full marks in mid terms and exams.
One of my mid-term paper below mean and one above, for exam i got above mean for one paper and the other paper unknown. Overall grade : B
reviews.comment_workload: There was actually no work to do at all. Only Prof. Renneberg woud give out homework but they were all optional. If you handed in, you will get extra points.

reviews.author: Johnette
reviews.comment_content:
dse chemistry and biology
teaches organic compounds, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, dna
easy to handle if you took dse chem and bio
reviews.comment_teaching:
3 profs teaching different parts
one of them has terrible accent making me not quite comfortable listening to him
he keeps "ahhhh....ahhhhhh........."
reviews.comment_grading:
I got overall 9x% and A-
I think the final is too easy and coz it is open book, many people score high marks
reviews.comment_workload:
zoom for whole semester so onle 1 midterm plus 1 final
no assignment/iprs at all
didn't even have lectures for a few weeks

reviews.author: u trust me (?)
reviews.comment_content: Quite difficult for students with no science background
reviews.comment_teaching:
Herrup's lesson is easy to understand and clear. The content is the same as lifs1902.
Raymond's lesson is interesting but need to sit for the class since the video quality is not that good and the power point cannot provide sufficient information for examination. Stefan's lesson is quite boring. However, his PowerPoint is the best. He will also provide sample papers for practice.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite fair.
content:
before midterm:
Microscopy – The art of seeing the small
Chemistry in water, strong and weak interactions
The chemistry of sugars
Sugar chains make carbohydrates
The chemistry of nucleic acids
The double helix and beyond
The chemistry of amino acids and peptides
How to build a three-dimensional protein
Proteins in motion – the example of contraction
Proteins in motion- enzymatic catalysis The chemistry of lipids
After midterm:
     Evolution of membranes / systems I  
Evolution of membranes / systems
Life molecules for health / diseases (Food & health through metabolism I)    
Food & health through metabolism II   
Food & health through metabolism III  
Evolution - the business of genetics    
The marvelous mitochondrion
Analytical systems: Monitoring of health and disease
Inform yourself! Use your nervous system
Human Intelligence / Revision / Questions
From one cell to many – development of an organism
Aging
reviews.comment_workload: No homework at all

reviews.author: MariaCao
reviews.title: Difficult course for me
reviews.comment_content: Chemistry part before midterm and life science part after midterm. A lot of things to learn and remember. The chemistry part is quite difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Nagl teaches chemistry part and I really can't understand his German English. He talked about many things that I haven't even heard before.
Prof. Wong is better; at least I can understand him. His part of content is quite interesting.
Prof. Herrup is the best. His teaching is clear and interesting, and the content is not that difficult.
reviews.comment_grading: The final result was unclear so I cannot compare mine to others. But taking this course, you are competing with students even in year 3 or 4 who major in chemistry or life science, and it's a huge challenge to year 1 students. My grade is not good.
reviews.comment_workload: No assignment so no workload for that, but you need to spend a lot of time understanding the things if you are not in chemistry or life science major.

reviews.author: Kairland
reviews.comment_content: 很多常识性内容，高中学过化学和生物几乎不用听
reviews.comment_teaching: 德国教授的口音有一点点难听懂，但是ppt里面讲的很详细了
reviews.comment_grading:
可以说是究极神龟课了
Midterm: 32/30 (Including Bonus of 2 points, Mean: 25.25) 50%
Final: 39/45 (Mean: 36.99) 30%
Term Paper: 79/100 (Mean: 78.21) 20%
Overall: 95.1%
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: 没有作业，学期内workload约等于没有，只有期末的时候有一个Term Paper要写（两到三千词左右）
